title: Vachon River (Arnaud River tributary)
text:
Vachon River (, <a href="Inuktitut">Inuktitut</a>: "Ikkatujaaq (seemingly shallow)" or "Qarnatulik (unknown meaning)" or "Avaluko (unknown meaning)") is a <a href="river">river</a> in the <a href="Arctic%20tundra">Arctic tundra</a> of <a href="Nunavik">Nunavik</a>, <a href="Quebec">Quebec</a>. It originates on Lac Laflamme at just north of <a href="Pingualuit%20crater">Pingualuit crater</a> and finishes at where it joins <a href="Arnaud%20River">Arnaud/Payne River</a>. It was named after <a href="bishop">bishop</a> Alexander Vachon (1885–1953), <a href="Rector%20%28academia%29">rector</a> of <a href="Laval%20University">Laval University</a> in 1939 and from 1940 to 1953, <a href="archbishop">archbishop</a> of the <a href="diocese">diocese</a> of <a href="Ottawa%2C%20Ontario">Ottawa, Ontario</a>.
Despite the access and <a href="canoe%20camping">paddling</a> difficulties (long <a href="whitewater">rapids and ledges</a>) and extreme <a href="Climate">climatic conditions</a>, river is occasionally <a href="Canoeing">paddled</a> by <a href="canoe">canoe</a>ists:
River is inhabited by an important <a href="Arctic%20char">Arctic char</a> population harvested for subsistence by the <a href="Inuit">Inuit</a> of <a href="Kangirsuk%2C%20Quebec">Kangirsuk</a>.
